subject: Re: [junit] Priority of Assertion?
msgSnippet: Yes, it requires state, yes there has been confusion by enduesers. The most common confusion is that execution does not continue after an
messageBody:
Yes, it requires state, yes there has been confusion by enduesers. The most
common confusion is that execution does not continue after an
expectThatExceptionThrown statement as it would with a try/catch statement.
The confusion however does not last for very long and a lot of people seem
to like it quite a lot. But it is a magic trick that does not share it's
secrets to the casual observer. That is a weakness.

> On Mon, Jan 5, 2009 at 9:21 AM, Joakim Ohlrogge

>
> > In rMock we used the following contruct:
> >
> > public void testSomething() {
> > <code that we don't expect to throw an exception>
> > expectThatExceptionThrown(isInstanceOf(SomeException.class));
> > <code that we expect to throw an exception>
> > }
>
> My initial reaction is that that construct would need global state, or a
> tricky simulation thereof, which I worry about causing more confusion than
> it solves. What has the user experience been?
>
> My favorite solution, which I've reimplemented several times, but never
> widely released (except maybe in the test utilities of the defunct Popper
> library), is described here:
>
> http://shareandenjoy.saff.net/2006/12/assertthrownexception_20.html
>
> It requires imposterization magic too powerful for casual inclusion in
> JUnit
> or jMock, but whose time will come, oh yes, it will come.
